text: We'll hear argument first this morning in No. 91-2045, R. Gordon Darby v. Henry Cisneros.
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Mr. Gordon, what if your client had, in fact, taken an appeal within the agency?
Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
Is it your view that 10(a) creates the exhaustion doctrine, codifies the exhaustion doctrine?
--It's my view that... it's our view that section 10(a) is the... is the basic provision that gives you a right of action for judicial review.
Well, before the... and that's what requires exhaustion.
And what language in 10(a) requires exhaustion?
I'd like to address several points, if I may.
Do you know any cases, Mr. Gordon, in which the concept of finality was applied to failure to seek an appeal within the agency?
--No, Justice Scalia, I do not, sir.
I would also... on the facts here, the Government has pooh-poohed the notion that the LDP, which was in effect throughout, had much of an impact on Mr. Darby.
